description: Excel is more than just columns and rows of data. Excel can perform calculations from simple addition to complex formulas with its vast library of named functions. In this series, we cover everything you need to know about crunching numbers in Excel. There are multiple sections ranging from the very basics to more advanced data analysis to a reference guide of the different Excel functions by category. This series is for beginners as well as advanced users of Excel.

name: Excel Functions
subtitle: Excel functions are fun

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne start the Excel Functions series by laying down some foundational knowledge and terminology. Specific concepts/definitions discussed here include: formulas, functions, relative reference, absolute reference, and named ranges.
episodes.title: Introduction to Excel Function

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne introduce basic formulas in Excel. Specific topics covered here include: formula format, cell references, order of operations, updating formulas, calculating formulas across worksheets, and common errors.
episodes.title: Basic Formulas

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne introduce basic functions in Excel. Specific topics include: navigating the formulas tab, categories of functions, Insert Function dialog box, descriptions of functions, and following steps in the function dialog box.
episodes.title: Basic Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne continue their introduction to working with basic functions in Excel. Specific topics include: using the AutoSum function, relative reference, and absolute reference.
episodes.title: Basic Functions Part 2

episodes.description: While function syntax is the same in all platforms, there are a few nuances  using functions in Excel for Mac. In this episode, Vonne and Justin identify a few key differences in the Mac interface when inserting functions.
episodes.title: Functions in Mac

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin demonstrate some helpful shortcuts for working with functions including shortcuts for copying functions, absolute reference, and paste as values.
episodes.title: Keyboard Shortcuts for Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore working with named ranges in Excel functions and formulas. Here, they will show: how to create a named range, naming conventions, access the Name Manager, use the helper, create named ranges from a selection, delete named ranges, and use named ranges in formulas.
episodes.title: Named Ranges

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explain the use of 3D cell references. Topics include: creating 3D cell references, performing 3D calculations, and copying additional sheets into workbook formulas.
episodes.title: 3D Cell Reference

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach discuss how to check for errors in formulas and functions. The topics covered include: trace precedents and dependents, error checking, evaluate formula, trace error, and types of errors.
episodes.title: Formula Auditing

episodes.description: Adding up numbers is one the most commonly used tasks in Excel. In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the SUM function, including shortcuts and tricks.
episodes.title: SUM

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the SUMIF function. SUMIF adds a range of numbers based on single criteria.
episodes.title: SUMIF

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the SUMIFS function. SUMIFS adds a range of numbers based on multiple criteria.
episodes.title: SUMIFS

episodes.description: The COUNT functions are a set of popular functions that, well, count! In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the COUNT, COUNTA, COUNTBLANK functions to count numbers (COUNT), any content (COUNTA), and number of blank cells (COUNTBLANK).
episodes.title: COUNT, COUNTA, COUNTBLANK

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the COUNTIF and COUNTIFS functions. These functions count the number of occurrences based on singular (COUNTIF) and multiple (COUNTIFS) criteria.
episodes.title: COUNTIF, COUNTIFS

episodes.description: The AVERAGE function is used to find the arithmetic mean of a range of numbers. In other words, add them up and divide by the number of items. The AVERAGEA is used to evaluate if text is present in the range.
episodes.title: AVERAGE, AVERAGEA

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin explore how to use the AVERAGEIF and AVERAGEIFS functions. These functions return the average of a group of numbers of based on singular (COUNTIF) and multiple (COUNTIFS) criteria.
episodes.title: AVERAGEIF, AVERAGEIFS

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin explore functions that return the minimum (MIN) and maximum (MAX) values within a range. The SMALL function returns the smallest designated position within a range, for example, the 3rd smallest value. The LARGE returns the largest designated position. They also discuss the MINA and MAXA functions, which does not ignore text.
episodes.title: MIN, MAX, SMALL, LARGE

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin explore functions that return the minimum (MINIFS) and maximum (MAXIFS) values within a range based on a specified set of conditions or criteria.  These functions require an Office 365 subscription
episodes.title: MINIFS, MAXIFS

episodes.description: The RAND function returns a random number between 0 and 1 while the RANDBETWEEN allows a user to specify the range of the generated random number, for example, between 5 and 50.
episodes.title: RAND, RANDBETWEEN

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin discuss dates and date formatting in this episode. They demonstrate the basic TODAY and NOW functions and examples of when are where to use them. They also talk about 1900 vs 1904 date systems.
episodes.title: TODAY, NOW

episodes.description: The MONTH, DAY, and YEAR functions will return the month, day, and year from a date as a number. The TEXT function converts a number to text based on designated format codes. For example, TEXT can be used to convert 6 to June.
episodes.title: MONTH, DAY, YEAR, TEXT

episodes.description: CONCAT and TEXTJOIN are two functions that join together (concatenates) text from cells. These functions require an Office 365 subscription and replace the CONCATENATE function.
episodes.title: CONCAT, TEXTJOIN

episodes.description: LEFT, RIGHT, and MID are popular text functions to extract characters from the left, right and middle of a text string.
episodes.title: LEFT, RIGHT, MID

episodes.description: These text functions are used to change case to all capital letters (UPPER), all lowercase letters (LOWER), or capitalize the first letter of each word (PROPER) of a text string in a cell.
episodes.title: UPPER, LOWER, PROPER

episodes.description: TRIM is an easy way to clean up extra spaces in the beginning and ending of a string of text. The CLEAN function will remove nonprintable characters; however, it's not as straight forward as one might think.  Both functions can be used to clean up text imported from other applications or operating systems.
episodes.title: TRIM, CLEAN

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin geek out on one of Vonne's favorite subjects - character sets. They discuss these lesser known functions as well as how and when to use them.
episodes.title: CHAR, CODE, UNICHAR, UNICODE

episodes.description: These two functions do exactly what it sounds like they do - replace and substitute text. Vonne and Justin demonstrate these functions with some basic examples.
episodes.title: REPLACE, SUBSTITUTE

episodes.description: The FIND and SEARCH functions are two self-evident functions that find and search characters and/or strings of text within a cell.
episodes.title: FIND, SEARCH

episodes.description: The LEN function returns the length of a string. On its own, the function is not overly helpful. However, it is widely used in combination with other text functions to find, extract, and replace text.
episodes.title: LEN

episodes.description: One of the most popular functions, the IF function performs a logical test and returns one value if true, another if false. Vonne and Justin discuss the power and potential of this function and show some basic examples.
episodes.title: IF

episodes.description: AND and OR are two logical functions to determine if conditions are TRUE or FALSE. These functions are most commonly used with the IF function.
episodes.title: AND, OR

episodes.description: Get ready for some confusion. Vonne and Justin switch things up to discuss the NOT function.  The NOT function is used to test if a value does not equal another.
episodes.title: NOT

episodes.description: The MATCH function finds a specified value in a range and returns its position with that range.  This function is widely used with the INDEX function as a prominent option for lookup functions.
episodes.title: MATCH

episodes.description: The INDEX function returns a value based on the specified position of the value within a range. While the description of the function is not very straight forward, Vonne and Justin demonstrate how useful the function is for users. They also combine INDEX with MATCH to show how to create dynamic lookups.
episodes.title: INDEX

episodes.description: One of the most popular functions, VLOOKUP finds a value in a range then returns another value in the same row based on the column number of the range. Vonne and Justin demonstrate with some basic examples and scenarios of when to use this function.
episodes.title: VLOOKUP

episodes.description: HLOOKUP is like VLOOKUP, just turned 90 degrees. HLOOKUP is used to lookup values when the data is arranged horizontally. The function will return a value in the same column based on the row reference.
episodes.title: HLOOKUP

episodes.description: LOOKUP was the predecessor to the VLOOKUP and HLOOKUP functions. While not as flexible, the LOOKUP function does have some good use case scenarios. Vonne and Justin demonstrate some of those scenarios in this episode.
episodes.title: LOOKUP

episodes.description: The CHOOSE function returns a value from a list based in the index number of said list. This function can be used as an alternative to nested IF functions. Vonne and Justin show and explain this function with different examples.
episodes.title: CHOOSE
